resources.string: The board has 64 squares. "Light on right" is the golden rule for setting it up correctly.
Pawns move forward but capture diagonally. Don\'t forget about En Passant!
The Knight moves in an L-shape and is the only piece that can jump over others.
The 4 central squares are critical. Controlling them gives your pieces mobility.
A fork is when one of your pieces attacks two or more enemy pieces simultaneously.
Bishops move diagonally as far as they want. You start with one light-squared and one dark-squared bishop.
Rooks move horizontally and vertically. They are powerful pieces, especially in the endgame.
The Queen is the most powerful piece, combining the movement of both the Rook and the Bishop.
The King moves one square in any direction. Protecting him is the most important goal of the game.
Castling gets your King to safety and brings your Rook into the game. Do it early!
Don\'t move the same piece twice in the opening. Get all your minor pieces out first.
A pin restricts a piece from moving because it would expose a more valuable piece behind it.
Similar to a pin, but the more valuable piece is in front. It moves, and the piece behind is lost.
Moving a piece to reveal an attack from a piece standing behind it. Often very deadly.
A situation where any move a player makes weakens their position. "Compulsion to move."
When a King is surrounded by his own pieces and cannot escape a Knight\'s check.
Checkmating the King on the back row because his own pawns block his escape.
When a pawn reaches the other side of the board, it can become a Queen, Rook, Bishop, or Knight.
If the King is not in check but has no legal moves, the game is a draw. Watch out for this!
Winning a Rook for a Knight or Bishop is called "winning the exchange."
In chess, time is measured in moves (tempo). Gaining a tempo means forcing the opponent to waste a move.
Sacrificing material (usually a pawn) in the opening to gain an advantage in position or development.
Developing the Bishop to the long diagonal (b2/g2 or b7/g7) to control the center from a distance.
After the opening, form a plan based on pawn structure, piece activity, and king safety.
Using your King to block the enemy King from advancing. Crucial in King and Pawn endgames.
If you are ahead by one pawn, try to exchange pieces (not pawns) to simplify into a winning endgame.
A key method for winning Rook and Pawn endgames. "Building a bridge" for your King.
A defensive setup to draw a Rook and Pawn endgame against a superior opponent.
Review your own games, especially losses, to understand your mistakes and learn from them.
Chess is a lifelong journey. Enjoy the process of learning and playing!
